def: {bc} the belief in a god or in a group of gods
{bc} an organized system of beliefs, ceremonies, and rules used to worship a god or a group of gods
{it}informal{/it} {bc} an interest, a belief, or an activity that is very important to a person or group

dt: {bc}the belief in a god or in a group of gods

dt.t: Many people turn to {it}religion{/it} for comfort in a time of crisis.

dt: {bc}an organized system of beliefs, ceremonies, and rules used to worship a god or a group of gods

dt.t: There are many {it}religions{/it}, such as Buddhism, Christianity, Hinduism, Islam, and Judaism.
Shinto is a {it}religion{/it} that is unique to Japan.
I think that children should be taught about different {it}religions{/it}. [={it}faiths{/it}]
It is against my {it}religion{/it} [=my beliefs do not allow me] to drink alcohol.
They advocated for {phrase}freedom of religion{/phrase}. [=the right to choose what religion to follow and to worship without interference]
She no longer participates in {phrase}organized religion{/phrase}. [=a belief system that has large numbers of followers and a set of rules that must be followed]

dt: {bc}an interest, a belief, or an activity that is very important to a person or group

dt.t: Hockey is a {it}religion{/it} in Canada.
Politics are a {it}religion{/it} to him.
Where I live, high school football is {it}religion{/it}.
Food is {it}religion{/it} in this house.

dt: {bc}to become religious {bc}to decide to follow a particular religion

dt.t: Lots of people {it}get religion{/it} in prison.
My dad {it}found religion{/it} after surviving a car accident.

dt: {bc}to stop doing something that others think is wrong and begin to do something others think is good or correct

dt.t: Automakers have {it}found religion{/it}, finally bringing more hybrid vehicles to market.
The mayor {it}got religion{/it} on public transit and is now pushing plans to build a new subway.

shortdef: the belief in a god or in a group of gods
an organized system of beliefs, ceremonies, and rules used to worship a god or a group of gods
an interest, a belief, or an activity that is very important to a person or group

def: {bc} to obtain (something) through effort, chance, etc.

dt.t: I have to {it}get{/it} an important message {it}to{/it} her at once!

dt.t: She never {it}got to go{/it} to college.

dt: {bc}to be given only slight or mild punishment for a crime or for doing something wrong

dt: {bc}to do enough or to do well enough to avoid failure

dt: {bc}to be able to live or to do what is needed by using what you have even though you do not have much

dt: {bc}to help (someone) to be judged not guilty

dt.t: His lawyer {it}got{/it} him {it}off{/it}.

dt: {bc}to be given or to help (someone) to be given only a slight punishment for a crime

dt.t: She {it}got off{/it} lightly.
He {it}got off with{/it} a light sentence.
His lawyer tried to {it}get{/it} him {it}off with{/it} a light sentence.
It was a bad accident. You're lucky that you {it}got off with{/it} just a broken leg—you could have been killed!

dt: {bc}to stop being on or against someone or something

dt.t: {it}Get off{/it}—you're hurting me!
I took the subway and {it}got off{/it} at the downtown station.

dt: {bc}to stop talking about (something) or to cause (someone) to stop talking about (something)

dt.t: We somehow {it}got off{/it} (the subject of) work and started talking about our personal lives.
I tried to change the subject, but I couldn't {it}get{/it} her {it}off{/it} it.

dt: {bc}to finish working and leave the place where you work

dt.t: I {it}get off{/it} early on Fridays.
I {it}got off work{/it} early last Thursday so I could see the parade.

dt: {bc}to write and send (a letter, an e-mail message, etc.)

dt.t: I'll {it}get{/it} the letter {it}off{/it} (to them) tomorrow.
The policeman {it}got off{/it} [={it}fired{/it}] several shots before the criminal escaped.
He managed to {it}get off{/it} a few good jokes in his speech.

dt: {bc}to fall asleep or to help (someone, such as a baby) to fall asleep

dt.t: I had just {it}got off{/it} [={it}dropped off{/it}] when the doorbell rang. = I had just {phrase}got off to sleep{/phrase} when the doorbell rang.
I just {it}got{/it} the baby {it}off to sleep{/it}.

dt: {bc}to have an orgasm or to cause (someone) to have an orgasm
{bc}to enjoy or be excited by (something) especially in a sexual way

dt.t: He's one of those guys who seem to {it}get off on{/it} making other people feel guilty.

dt: {bc}to have sex with (someone) {bc}to begin a sexual relationship with (someone)

dt.t: She found out he'd {it}gotten off with{/it} another woman.

dt: To {phrase}tell someone where to get off{/phrase} is to criticize or disagree with someone in a very direct and angry way.

dt.t: I was sick of listening to his constant complaints, so I {it}told him where to get off{/it}.

dt: If you {phrase}don't know where someone gets off{/phrase} (doing something), you are angry because someone has done something that is not right.

dt.t: I {it}don't know where he gets off{/it} telling me what to do. = {phrase}Where does he get off{/phrase} telling me what to do? [=he has no right to tell me what to do]
I didn't mean to interrupt you. I'll let you {it}get on with{/it} your work.
You need to stop feeling sorry for yourself and just {phrase}get on with your life{/phrase}. [=return to doing the things you do in your normal life]
This introduction is taking forever. I wish they'd just {phrase}get on with it{/phrase}. [=stop delaying and get to the interesting or important part]

dt: {bc}to be or remain friendly {bc}to get along

dt.t: They've never really {it}got on{/it} (with each other).
We {it}get on{/it} well enough, but we're not really close friends.
How is your daughter {it}getting on{/it} in/at school?
We can {it}get on{/it} [={it}get along, get by, manage{/it}] just fine without them.
an ambitious young woman trying to {it}get on{/it} in business

dt: {bc}to start to do or deal with (something)

dt.t: {ldquo}These files need to be organized.{rdquo} {ldquo}I'll {it}get on{/it} it right away.{rdquo}
His boss has been {it}getting on{/it} him about the quality of his work.
She's always {phrase}getting on his case{/phrase} about cleaning his room. [=she's always telling him to clean it]
My grandmother is {it}getting on{/it} [={it}aging{/it}] a bit, but she's still very active.
It's {it}getting on{/it}, and we really ought to go.

dt: {bc}to move toward becoming (a specified age, time, etc.)

dt.t: He's {it}getting on for{/it} 70. [=he's approaching 70; he is nearly 70]
It was {it}getting on for{/it} noon.

dt: {bc}to start to do or deal with (something)

dt.t: {ldquo}We need someone to send out the invitations.{rdquo} {ldquo}I'll {it}get onto{/it} [={it}get on{/it}] it right away.{rdquo}
How did we {it}get onto{/it} this topic?

dt: {bc}to speak to or write to (someone) about a particular problem, job, etc.

dt.t: I'll {it}get onto{/it} [={it}get in touch with{/it}] the doctor/plumber straightaway and see if he'll come round.

dt: {bc}to leave or escape from a place, a vehicle, etc.

dt.t: He was trapped in the burning building/car, but he was somehow able to {it}get out{/it} (of it) alive.

dt: used as an angry way to tell someone to leave

dt.t: {it}Get out{/it}! I never want to see you again!

dt: {bc}to cause or help (someone) to leave or escape

dt.t: The firemen managed to {it}get{/it} him {it}out{/it} (of the burning building) alive.

dt: {bc}to remove (something) from storage so that it can be used

dt.t: It's raining. I'd better {it}get out{/it} the umbrella.

dt: {bc}to go to places outside your home for social occasions, events, etc.

dt.t: You spend too much time at home. You need to {it}get out{/it} more.
Their secret {it}got out{/it}.
Word {it}got out{/it} that she was resigning.
He managed to {it}get out{/it} a few words before he collapsed.

dt: used in speech to show that you are surprised by something or do not believe it

dt.t: {ldquo}They gave the job to Jane.{rdquo} {ldquo}{it}Get out{/it}!{rdquo} = {ldquo}{phrase}Get out of here{/phrase}!{rdquo}

dt: {bc}to avoid doing (something) or to help (someone) to avoid doing (something)

dt.t: I didn't want to go to the lecture, but I couldn't {it}get out of{/it} it.
He tried to {it}get out of{/it} doing his homework.
My sister said she could {it}get{/it} me {it}out of{/it} going to the party if I really didn't want to go

dt: {bc}to stop having (a habit) or to cause (someone) to stop having (a habit)

dt.t: I used to exercise every day, but I {it}got out of{/it} the habit.
All the extra work I've been doing has {it}gotten{/it} me {it}out of{/it} the habit of exercising.

dt: {bc}to stop being in or involved in (something) or to cause (someone or something) to stop being in or involved in (something)

dt.t: The company has decided to {it}get{/it} (itself) {it}out of{/it} the computer business.
She {it}got{/it} her money {it}out of{/it} the stock market.
The police officer {it}got{/it} the gun {it}out of{/it} the suspect's hand.
The police officer {it}got{/it} a confession {it}out of{/it} the suspect.
What do you hope to {it}get out of{/it} this experience?

dt: {bc}to stop being controlled or bothered by (something, such as a problem or feeling)

dt.t: You need to {it}get over{/it} [={it}overcome{/it}] your fear of being lied to.
She's disappointed about their decision, but she'll {it}get over{/it} it eventually.

dt: used to say that you are very surprised or impressed by something

dt.t: I just can't {it}get over{/it} how much weight you've lost!
He had a bad cold, and he still hasn't {it}gotten over{/it} it completely.

dt: {bc}to stop feeling unhappy after ending a relationship with (someone)

dt.t: He broke up with his girlfriend a couple of months ago, and he still hasn't {it}gotten over{/it} her.

dt: {bc}to cause or experience the end of (something) {bc}to finish (something)

dt.t: I just want to {it}get{/it} this ordeal {it}over{/it}! = I just want to {it}get{/it} this ordeal {it}over with{/it}! = I just want to {phrase}get{/phrase} this ordeal {phrase}over and done with{/phrase}! [=I want this ordeal to end]

dt: {bc}to express (something) clearly so that it is understood

dt.t: I don't know if I was able to {it}get{/it} my message {it}over{/it} [={it}across{/it}] to them.

dt: {bc}to reach a goal {bc}to do what you are trying to do

dt.t: We haven't made a profit yet, but we'll {it}get there{/it} eventually. [=we'll make a profit eventually]

dt: {bc}to come closer to reaching a goal

dt.t: We haven't made a profit yet, but we're {it}getting there{/it}.
When you {it}get through{/it} (with that job), I've got something else for you to do.

dt: {bc}to do or finish (something, such as an amount of work)

dt.t: We {it}got through{/it} [={it}covered{/it}] all of the material that we wanted to cover.
There's still a lot of paperwork to be {it}gotten through{/it}.

dt: {bc}to complete or to help (someone) to complete (a test, an exam, etc.) successfully

dt.t: She studied hard and {it}got through{/it} [={it}passed{/it}] her exams.
The extra hours of study are what {it}got{/it} her {it}through{/it} her exams.

dt: {bc}to pass through or beyond something that blocks you or slows you down

dt.t: Traffic was very heavy, but we managed to {it}get through{/it} (it).
Rescuers are having trouble {it}getting through{/it} to the flood victims.

dt: {bc}to cause (something) to pass through or beyond something

dt.t: Traffic was very heavy, but we managed to {it}get{/it} our truck {it}through{/it} (it).
Rescuers are having trouble {it}getting{/it} supplies {it}through{/it} to the flood victims.

dt: {bc}to have the experience of living through (something that is difficult, dangerous, etc.)

dt.t: It was a very difficult time in our marriage, but we {it}got through{/it} it.
I don't know how those early settlers managed to {it}get through{/it} [={it}survive{/it}] the winter.
It was pure determination that {it}got{/it} them {it}through{/it} that crisis.
He {it}got through{/it} [={it}went through{/it}] all the money he inherited in just a few years.
They {it}got through{/it} [={it}went through{/it}] three bottles of wine with dinner.

dt: {bc}to be clearly expressed to and understood by someone

dt.t: I hope my message has finally {it}gotten through to{/it} you. [=I hope you finally understand my message]
I think my message finally {it}got through{/it}.

dt: {bc}to express something clearly so that it is understood by (someone)

dt.t: I've talked to him many times, but I just can't seem to {it}get through to{/it} him.
I hope I've finally {it}gotten{/it} my message {it}through to{/it} him.

dt: {bc}to make a successful telephone call to someone

dt.t: I tried to call home but I couldn't {it}get through{/it}.
Where were you? I've been trying to {it}get through to{/it} you (on the phone) all day!

dt: {bc}to be accepted or approved by an official group

dt.t: The bill finally {it}got through{/it} [={it}passed{/it}] and eventually became a law.
The bill finally {it}got through{/it} [={it}passed{/it}] Congress and eventually became a law.
She sometimes {it}gets to worrying{/it} over her health.
We {it}got to talking{/it} about old times.
The letter is on my desk, but I haven't {it}gotten to{/it} it yet.
I'll {it}get to{/it} the accounts as soon as I can.
All these delays are starting to {it}get to{/it} me.
The movie's sad ending really {it}got to{/it} me.

dt: {bc}to change or influence the behavior of (someone) wrongly or illegally by making threats, paying money, etc.

dt.t: The witness changed his story. Someone must have {it}gotten to{/it} him.
We {it}got to{/it} the station/airport just in time.
I'd like to {it}get together{/it} with you soon.
He often {it}gets together{/it} with his friends after work.

dt: {bc}to begin to have a sexual or romantic relationship

dt.t: He and his wife first {it}got together{/it} in college.

dt: {bc}to cause (people) to meet or to have a relationship

dt.t: Their shared interest in photography is what {it}got{/it} them {it}together{/it}.

dt: {bc}to agree to do or accept something

dt.t: The two sides have been unable to {it}get together on{/it} a new contract.

dt: {bc}to collect (things) or gather (people) into one place or group

dt.t: He {it}got together{/it} [={it}assembled{/it}] a great art collection.
The government {it}got together{/it} a group of experts to study the problem.
We're still trying to {it}get together{/it} [={it}obtain{/it}] the money we need to buy a new car.

dt: {bc}to begin to live in a good and sensible way {bc}to stop being confused, foolish, etc.

dt.t: His life got much better when he stopped drinking and {it}got his act together{/it}.

dt: {bc}to begin to function in a skillful or effective way

dt.t: The company finally {it}got its act together{/it} and started making a profit this year.
She finally {it}got to sleep{/it} after midnight.
We need to stop delaying and {it}get to work{/it}.

dt: {bc}to rise or to cause (someone) to rise after lying or sleeping in a bed

dt.t: I {it}got up{/it} [=got out of bed] early this morning.
I woke up early but I didn't {it}get up{/it} till later.
The alarm clock {it}got{/it} me {it}up{/it} earlier than usual.
He {it}got up{/it} to greet her when she entered the room.

dt: {bc}to produce (something, such as courage) in yourself by trying or making an effort

dt.t: He couldn't {it}get up{/it} the courage to ask her out on a date.
She was so tired she could hardly {it}get up{/it} the energy to make dinner.

dt: {bc}to prepare or organize (something that involves a group of people)

dt.t: They're trying to {it}get up{/it} a petition to have the movie theater reopened.

dros.drp: get up on the wrong side of the bed

shortdef: to obtain (something) through effort, chance, etc.
